Description: During routine in-process testing, assay results for Batch B25-001 were found to be out of specification (OOS) on initial analysis. Investigation identified that the mixing step exceeded the validated time range due to operator misinterpretation of the batch record instructions. The deviation was detected prior to batch release. No impact to previously released batches was identified, and the batch was placed on quality hold pending investigation and disposition.

A temperature excursion was observed in the finished goods warehouse when the monitoring system recorded temperatures above 25Â°C for approximately four hours. Review of data showed delayed response to the alarm notification. Impact assessment confirmed that affected lots remained within labeled stability allowances. The deviation was documented, and corrective actions were initiated to improve alarm response procedures.

During equipment setup for tablet compression, the punch lubrication system failed to dispense lubricant at the validated rate. The issue was identified after visual defects were observed on compressed tablets. Equipment logs indicated a mechanical blockage. The batch was rejected due to potential impact on content uniformity and tablet integrity. Maintenance and requalification activities were initiated.

A discrepancy was noted between the approved master batch record and the executed batch record regarding sampling frequency. The operator followed an outdated controlled copy. No product quality impact was identified, as all required samples were ultimately collected and tested within specification. The deviation was recorded to address document control and training gaps.

Incoming raw material lactose monohydrate failed identity testing upon receipt. Investigation revealed that the supplier provided material from an unapproved manufacturing site. The material was rejected and segregated. Supplier qualification records were reviewed, and a supplier corrective action request was issued to prevent recurrence.

During cleaning verification of the granulation equipment, swab results exceeded established residue limits. Review determined that the operator omitted a validated rinse step in the cleaning procedure. The equipment was re-cleaned and re-tested with acceptable results. No batches were processed on the equipment prior to resolution.

A batch manufacturing record was not reviewed within the required five business days due to QA staffing constraints. The delay did not impact batch release timelines or product quality. The deviation was documented to address procedural adherence and workload management within the quality unit.

During routine calibration, a balance used for dispensing active pharmaceutical ingredient was found to be out of tolerance. Historical review identified multiple batches weighed on the balance since the last acceptable calibration. Risk assessment concluded no significant impact based on redundant weight checks. The balance was removed from service and recalibrated.

An operator entered an incorrect lot number on the label reconciliation form during packaging operations. The error was detected during line clearance reconciliation. No mislabeled product was released. The deviation was recorded to reinforce data integrity and documentation accuracy expectations.

Environmental monitoring results from Grade C area showed elevated viable counts above alert limits. Investigation determined that cleaning frequency was insufficient during increased production activity. Enhanced cleaning was implemented, and subsequent monitoring results were within limits. No sterility assurance impact was identified.

A training record review revealed that a newly assigned operator performed equipment setup prior to completing required GMP training. The task was supervised, and no errors were observed. The deviation was documented to address training compliance and access control to manufacturing activities.

During stability testing, a long-term sample showed a marginal trend toward specification limits. Investigation linked the result to a brief temperature excursion during sample storage. The excursion remained within allowable limits, and no formal OOS occurred. Enhanced monitoring controls were implemented.

A batch was rejected after dissolution results failed to meet specification during final testing. Investigation identified inadequate granulation moisture control due to inconsistent process monitoring. Corrective actions included revision of in-process controls and retraining of manufacturing staff.

An unapproved pen was observed being used to complete GMP documentation on the manufacturing floor. Although the entries were legible and accurate, the deviation was recorded to reinforce data integrity requirements and controlled documentation practices.

A preventive maintenance activity on the coating pan was performed later than the scheduled interval. Review of equipment performance showed no abnormalities. The deviation was documented to improve maintenance planning and tracking within the computerized maintenance management system.

Raw material packaging was found damaged upon receipt, with potential risk of contamination. The material was quarantined and inspected. No contamination was detected, but the shipment was rejected as a precaution. Supplier handling practices were reviewed.

During media fill simulation, an operator deviated from the approved aseptic technique by reaching over open containers. The simulation was failed, and a full investigation was conducted. Retraining and requalification of involved personnel were required.

A deviation was opened when an electronic batch record system experienced temporary downtime, requiring use of paper backup records. Data reconciliation confirmed completeness and accuracy. System validation and IT controls were reviewed.

Cleaning validation acceptance criteria were not met for one sampling location during routine verification. Investigation identified worn gaskets as a potential source of residue retention. Gaskets were replaced and the equipment was revalidated.

During packaging operations, line clearance was initiated before completion of reconciliation from the previous batch. The issue was identified immediately, and operations were halted. No mix-up occurred. The deviation was documented to reinforce procedural compliance.

An SOP revision was implemented without updating the associated training matrix. As a result, impacted personnel were not retrained in a timely manner. No operational errors were linked to the lapse. The deviation addressed document change management controls.

A humidity excursion was recorded in the raw material storage area due to HVAC malfunction. Assessment confirmed that affected materials were moisture stable. Maintenance repairs were completed, and environmental monitoring was enhanced.

A supplier change notification for a critical excipient was not communicated to QA prior to receipt. The material was placed on hold until qualification was completed. Supplier oversight processes were revised.
During visual inspection, an increased reject rate was observed for cosmetic defects. Investigation linked the issue to worn tooling. Tooling was replaced, and reject rates returned to baseline.

An analyst used an expired reference standard during HPLC system suitability testing. The error was detected during peer review. Testing was repeated using a qualified standard, with acceptable results.

Batch documentation contained missing operator initials for one processing step. Interview confirmed the step was performed as required. The deviation was recorded to emphasize real-time documentation practices.
A deviation was initiated when compressed air quality test results exceeded action limits. Investigation identified a compromised filter. The system was repaired and requalified prior to use.
During annual product review, a trend of minor weight variability was noted. Although within specification, the deviation was documented to proactively address process capability and control.

An incorrect cleaning agent concentration was prepared due to calculation error. The solution was not used, and the error was detected during QA verification. Retraining on calculation procedures was completed.

Warehouse staff stored a temperature-sensitive intermediate outside the designated cold room for approximately 30 minutes. Stability data supported no impact. The deviation reinforced material handling requirements.
An audit trail review identified unauthorized user access to a laboratory system. No data manipulation was detected. User access controls were revised, and the incident was documented.
During blending, segregation was observed due to incorrect blender load configuration. The batch was rejected due to potential content uniformity risk. Process parameters were updated.
A cleaning log entry was completed after the activity rather than contemporaneously. While no impact was identified, the deviation addressed ALCOA principles.
Environmental monitoring plates were incubated at an incorrect temperature. Results were invalidated and re-sampling was performed. No adverse trends were identified.
A training effectiveness assessment revealed that an operator misunderstood critical control points in granulation. No errors had occurred. The deviation resulted in enhanced training materials.
During API dispensing, a barcode scanner malfunction caused manual entry of material codes. Verification confirmed correct material usage. The scanner was repaired.
A supplier certificate of analysis was missing required test results upon receipt. Material was quarantined until corrected documentation was provided.
During qualification, a temperature mapping probe was found misplaced, invalidating the study. The qualification was repeated with correct setup.
An SOP referenced an obsolete regulatory guideline. The deviation was documented to ensure alignment with current regulatory expectations.
A batch experienced foaming during solution preparation due to incorrect agitation speed. The batch was rejected following investigation.
Cleaning validation documentation was incomplete due to missing attachments. The deviation addressed record completeness.
A power interruption caused temporary shutdown of lyophilization equipment. Process data review confirmed no impact to critical parameters.
An operator failed to follow gowning sequence in a controlled area. The incident was observed and corrected immediately.
A label roll was staged in the wrong packaging room. Line clearance prevented use. The deviation reinforced segregation controls.
An analytical method deviation occurred when a non-validated column was used. Testing was repeated using the validated method.
A deviation was opened due to delayed review of environmental monitoring trends. No adverse impact was identified.
An equipment logbook was not available at point of use due to misfiling. The issue was corrected, and documentation controls were reviewed.
During packaging, torque verification was missed at one interval. Subsequent checks were acceptable. Risk assessment supported batch release.
A training curriculum did not include recent SOP updates. No deviations resulted, but the gap was documented.
A minor crack was observed on a non-product contact surface of a mixing vessel. Engineering assessed no impact to product quality. Repair was scheduled.

During routine reconciliation of printed packaging components, a discrepancy was identified between issued and returned labels for Batch P25-014. Investigation confirmed that the count error resulted from manual miscounting during line clearance. All finished product units were reconciled and confirmed correct. No impact to labeling accuracy or patient safety was identified. The deviation was recorded to address reconciliation practices and reinforce double-check requirements during packaging operations.

An HVAC alarm indicated a pressure differential excursion between Grade B and adjacent Grade C areas during aseptic filling. The excursion lasted approximately six minutes before being corrected. Environmental monitoring data showed no adverse trends. Root cause was traced to a faulty pressure sensor requiring replacement. The deviation was documented due to potential impact on aseptic conditions, although no sterility assurance breach was identified.

During review of supplier documentation, it was identified that the change notification for a revised synthesis step of the API was received after material shipment. The material was placed on quality hold pending impact assessment. Additional testing and risk evaluation concluded no adverse impact to quality attributes. Supplier change communication processes were reviewed and strengthened.

A manufacturing operator deviated from the validated sieve size during dry granulation due to availability constraints. The deviation was identified during batch record review. Investigation concluded that the change could impact particle size distribution and dissolution. The batch was rejected, and corrective actions included improved material staging and escalation procedures.

An internal audit identified that periodic review of logbooks for a compression machine had not been performed according to SOP requirements. No undocumented activities were identified upon retrospective review. The deviation addressed procedural adherence and quality oversight rather than direct product quality impact.

During analytical testing, system suitability criteria were initially not met due to unstable baseline response. Investigation identified air bubbles in the mobile phase line caused by improper degassing. After correction, system suitability passed and sample results were acceptable. The deviation was documented to reinforce proper method setup.

A power fluctuation caused brief interruption of automated vial washing equipment. Cycle parameters were reviewed and confirmed to have resumed correctly. No partially washed vials were used. The deviation was documented due to equipment interruption in a critical process step.

Training records indicated that annual gowning qualification for one operator had expired prior to participation in Grade B operations. The operator was supervised, and no gowning errors were observed. The deviation addressed training compliance and tracking controls.

During cleaning verification, visual inspection identified residual powder accumulation beneath removable equipment guards. The cleaning SOP did not clearly specify removal of these guards. The deviation resulted in SOP revision and retraining. No batches were processed prior to correction.

An OOS result was generated for moisture content during in-process testing. Investigation confirmed instrument calibration drift due to overdue maintenance. Retesting using a calibrated instrument produced acceptable results. Impact assessment confirmed no batch quality impact.

A deviation was initiated when a batch manufacturing step exceeded the validated hold time due to unplanned shift change delays. Stability data supported acceptability of the extended hold. The event was documented to improve scheduling and communication controls.

During receipt inspection, outer packaging of a temperature-sensitive excipient showed evidence of condensation. Data logger review confirmed temperature remained within acceptable limits. The material was released with documented justification.

An incorrect version of a test method was referenced during analyst training. Although testing was performed correctly, the documentation discrepancy was recorded to address training material control.

Environmental monitoring trending identified repeated alert-level recoveries near a material transfer door. Investigation determined that door opening frequency increased during peak operations. Engineering and procedural controls were implemented to mitigate airflow disruption.

A deviation was opened when a balance failed daily verification due to worn load cells. The balance was removed from service. Review confirmed no impact to previously weighed materials due to secondary verification steps.

An operator failed to document completion time for a blending step in the batch record. Interview and supporting equipment data confirmed execution within validated parameters. The deviation addressed documentation completeness.

During annual requalification, a cleanroom airflow visualization study showed minor turbulence near an unused port. Engineering assessed no risk to product exposure. The deviation was documented for facility improvement tracking.
A deviation was initiated when a reagent used for analytical testing was found past its assigned in-use expiry. Testing was repeated with qualified reagent, yielding consistent results.
Supplier-provided sterilization certificates for primary packaging components were incomplete upon receipt. Components were quarantined until full documentation was obtained and reviewed.

A batch was placed on hold after coating thickness variability exceeded in-process limits. Investigation identified inconsistent spray rate due to nozzle wear. The batch was rejected due to potential dissolution impact.
A deviation was opened due to delayed approval of a critical SOP revision following regulatory update. No non-compliant activities occurred during the delay.

An operator incorrectly interpreted a torque specification as a range rather than a target value during packaging setup. The issue was identified during QA verification prior to operation. The deviation addressed training effectiveness.
An electronic alarm notification failed to transmit to the on-call phone during a weekend temperature excursion. Manual review identified the issue. IT controls and redundancy measures were enhanced.
A deviation was recorded when a batch record page was scanned incorrectly, resulting in incomplete electronic archive. The original hardcopy record was intact and verified.
During dispensing, an operator selected an incorrect scoop size but corrected the error prior to weighing. No incorrect material quantities were used. The deviation reinforced dispensing controls.
Compressed air testing showed oil vapor levels approaching action limits. Investigation traced the issue to a degrading compressor seal. Maintenance actions were taken and system requalified.
A training deviation was initiated when refresher GMP training was completed late for several warehouse staff. No handling errors were identified.
An unplanned shutdown of the purified water system occurred during sanitization. Review confirmed no distribution to manufacturing occurred during the event.
An analyst deviated from the validated sample sonication time during dissolution testing. Repeat testing was required. No impact to released product occurred.
During routine inspection, corrosion was noted on a non-product contact support structure in the blending suite. Engineering assessed no contamination risk. Repair was scheduled.
A deviation was opened when an SOP referenced an outdated acceptance criterion. No testing failures occurred.
Environmental monitoring plates were exposed beyond validated time during sampling. Results were invalidated and resampling conducted.
A batch experienced delayed transfer to drying due to equipment availability. Hold time was exceeded but supported by stability data.
A supplier failed to notify of minor formulation aid change. Risk assessment confirmed no impact to quality.
Packaging line clearance documentation was missing QA verification signature at time of operation. Signature was obtained retrospectively following confirmation of clearance.
An operator failed to remove previous batch status label from equipment prior to setup. The issue was identified during pre-use check.
A deviation was initiated due to repeated minor excursions in humidity trends during monsoon season. HVAC capacity review was initiated.
A reagent preparation worksheet contained a calculation error detected during QA review. The reagent was discarded and remade.
During maintenance, an incorrect gasket material was temporarily installed. The issue was identified before equipment use.
A training assessment revealed misunderstanding of data integrity requirements related to audit trails. No data issues were found.
An OOT trend was identified for tablet hardness during stability review. Investigation initiated to monitor long-term process capability.
A deviation was recorded due to missing temperature chart printout for one shipment. Electronic data was available and reviewed.
A batch experienced segregation during transfer due to improper chute alignment. The batch was rejected.
Warehouse mapping study identified a cold spot below alert limits. Corrective actions were implemented.
A supplier CoA was found to be unsigned. Material was placed on hold until corrected documentation received.
During gowning qualification, an operator touched a non-classified surface. The run was invalidated.
A deviation was initiated due to overdue review of cleaning validation protocol. No cleaning failures occurred.
A tablet press experienced intermittent feeder blockage. Investigation identified powder flow issues.
Incorrect sampling thief was selected during blend uniformity sampling. Samples were re-collected correctly.
A minor leak was observed in a utility water line outside production areas. No impact to GMP systems was identified.
A data integrity review identified shared user credentials on a legacy system. Access controls were updated.
An operator missed a scheduled in-process pH check due to shift handover miscommunication. Subsequent checks were acceptable.
During receipt, secondary packaging components were staged outside the designated quarantine area. No mix-up occurred.
A deviation was opened when an SOP effective date was incorrectly entered into the document control system.
Environmental monitoring incubator temperature was found slightly outside range during incubation. Plates were re-incubated.
A training deviation occurred when contractor GMP induction was completed after site access was granted.
During blending, load verification was not documented at the required frequency. Equipment data confirmed compliance.
A deviation was initiated due to delayed review of OOS investigation report. No release delays occurred.
A supplier-provided stability commitment letter was missing from the qualification package.
A batch failed friability testing due to insufficient binder distribution. The batch was rejected.
A deviation was recorded for incorrect waste labeling in a manufacturing suite. No cross-contamination risk identified.
An equipment alarm was disabled during troubleshooting without documentation. The issue was corrected immediately.
Environmental monitoring sample location was incorrectly documented. Actual location met requirements.
A deviation was initiated due to late completion of annual GMP refresher training for QA staff.
A batch experienced color variation during coating. Investigation identified pigment dispersion issue.
A deviation was opened due to incomplete deviation closure documentation. No quality impact occurred.
An operator selected an incorrect filter pore size during solution filtration. The issue was identified before use.
Compressed gas cylinder labeling was found partially damaged during inspection. Cylinders were replaced.
A deviation was recorded when trending of complaint data was not performed per schedule.
An unqualified software patch was temporarily applied to a non-critical system. The change was reverted.
A temperature probe failed calibration due to sensor drift. Historical data review showed no excursions.
During dispensing, line-of-sight segregation was briefly compromised due to space constraints.
An SOP revision omitted reference to an associated form. The deviation addressed documentation completeness.
A deviation was initiated due to delayed response to an environmental alert alarm.
An operator failed to sign off a critical step in real time. Signature was added later with justification.
A batch experienced inconsistent fill volumes due to pump wear. The batch was rejected.
A training matrix did not reflect recent role changes for manufacturing staff.
A deviation was recorded for incomplete reconciliation of returned bulk containers. Investigation confirmed accuracy.
An environmental monitoring trend showed gradual increase in non-viable counts. Preventive maintenance initiated.
A reagent label was partially illegible due to solvent exposure. The reagent was discarded.
A deviation was opened when batch release checklist was missing one attachment.
An operator bypassed an interlock during equipment cleaning without authorization. No operation occurred.
A deviation was initiated due to late initiation of an investigation beyond SOP timelines.
During solution preparation, mixing speed exceeded validated range briefly. Impact assessment showed no effect.
An environmental monitoring settle plate was overturned during exposure. Sample was invalidated.
A deviation was recorded when warehouse pest control logs were incomplete.
A supplier audit identified deficiencies in documentation practices. No impacted material was received.
An SOP training quiz did not cover newly added critical steps.
A deviation was opened when an analyst failed to save raw data files to the designated server.
A batch experienced unexpected viscosity increase during solution preparation. Root cause under investigation.
A deviation was initiated due to missing review of calibration records during internal audit.
An operator selected incorrect PPE for a controlled area. The issue was corrected immediately.
A deviation was opened due to delayed disposal of rejected material beyond SOP timeframe.
An environmental monitoring incubator experienced brief power loss. Plates were evaluated and deemed acceptable.
A deviation was recorded when cleaning verification results were not trended quarterly.
A batch failed appearance specification due to particulate matter. The batch was rejected.
A deviation was initiated due to incomplete handover documentation between shifts.
An equipment status label was missing from a cleaned vessel. Status was confirmed verbally.
A training deviation occurred when an SOP assessment was not completed within required timeframe.
A deviation was opened due to late closure of CAPA effectiveness check. No recurrence observed.

During routine in-process monitoring, blend uniformity samples showed increased relative standard deviation compared to historical performance, though still within specification. Investigation identified inconsistent sampling technique between operators during thief insertion. No batch impact was identified, and product was released. The deviation was documented to address sampling consistency and reinforce standardized technique through retraining and SOP clarification.

A temperature excursion occurred in the API quarantine room when the HVAC unit shut down unexpectedly overnight. The excursion lasted approximately two hours before correction. Review of stability data confirmed no impact to material quality. Maintenance replaced a faulty control relay, and alarm escalation procedures were reviewed.

During review of executed batch records, it was identified that one critical processing step was signed by a second operator rather than the individual performing the activity. Interviews confirmed the step was completed correctly. The deviation addressed documentation integrity and contemporaneous recording expectations.

An OOS result for impurity level was observed during release testing. Investigation determined the chromatographic column had exceeded its validated usage life, affecting resolution. Testing was repeated with a qualified column, yielding acceptable results. Column lifecycle management controls were strengthened.

A deviation was opened when a supplier shipment arrived without required tamper-evident seals. The material was quarantined pending investigation. Supplier confirmed a packaging deviation at their facility. Material was rejected as a precaution.

During cleaning verification, rinse water conductivity results exceeded alert limits. Investigation identified incomplete drain-down of the system prior to final rinse. The system was re-cleaned and re-tested successfully. No manufacturing occurred between cleaning cycles.

An internal audit identified that annual review of a validated spreadsheet used for yield calculations was overdue. No errors were identified in historical use. The deviation addressed validation lifecycle management.

A compression machine experienced intermittent main drive alarms during operation. The batch was stopped and placed on hold. Maintenance identified a failing motor bearing. Due to potential impact on compression force consistency, the batch was rejected.

During packaging operations, an operator briefly staged printed leaflets outside the designated line area. Line clearance controls prevented use. The deviation was documented to reinforce material segregation practices.

Environmental monitoring trending showed repeated alert-level non-viable particle counts near a filling needle. Investigation identified worn seals contributing to turbulence. Seals were replaced and the line requalified.

A deviation was opened when an analyst failed to document mobile phase preparation lot numbers in the laboratory notebook. Supporting records confirmed traceability. Documentation practices were reinforced.
A raw material was dispensed using a balance that had not yet undergone daily verification. Secondary verification confirmed correct weight. The deviation addressed equipment use controls.

During annual media fill review, it was identified that one simulation exceeded the maximum number of permitted interventions due to training activities. Although no contamination was observed, the run was invalidated and repeated.
A deviation was initiated due to late initiation of stability pull testing beyond the scheduled window. Samples remained under controlled storage. No data integrity issues were identified.
During warehouse inspection, a pallet of secondary packaging was found leaning due to improper stacking. No damage occurred. The deviation addressed material handling and storage practices.
An SOP governing cleaning agent preparation referenced an obsolete concentration range. The deviation was documented to align procedures with validated cleaning parameters.
A deviation was opened when a blister machine sealing temperature briefly exceeded the validated range due to sensor lag. Product inspection showed no defects. Engineering recalibrated the sensor.
An analyst deviated from the validated centrifugation speed during sample preparation. The error was identified during peer review, and testing was repeated correctly.
Supplier audit findings identified inadequate change control documentation at an excipient manufacturer. No impacted material was in use. Enhanced supplier oversight was implemented.
A deviation was initiated when environmental monitoring plates were incubated in the wrong sequence, delaying result availability. No adverse trends were identified.
During filling operations, an operator failed to perform a required in-process weight check at the scheduled interval. Subsequent checks were within limits. Risk assessment supported batch release.
A deviation was recorded due to incomplete reconciliation documentation for returned printed components. Physical counts confirmed accuracy.
An unplanned shutdown of the purified water generation system occurred during routine sanitization. No manufacturing activities were impacted.
A training deviation was opened when aseptic technique requalification was completed one week past due. No aseptic processing occurred during the lapse.
A batch experienced delayed drying due to equipment availability, resulting in extended wet mass hold time. Stability data supported acceptability.
During routine inspection, cracks were observed on a non-product contact floor surface in the dispensing area. Facility repair was scheduled.
An operator entered an incorrect date format in an electronic batch record field. The error was corrected with audit trail documentation.
A deviation was opened when an HPLC autosampler needle was found bent during maintenance. No samples were affected.
Incoming primary packaging components arrived with mixed pallet labeling. Components were segregated and verified before release.
Environmental monitoring results showed a single action-level recovery in a Grade C area. Investigation identified improper cleaning of a drain. Corrective cleaning was performed.
A deviation was initiated when an SOP training acknowledgment was missing for one operator. Training was confirmed verbally and re-documented.
During coating operations, spray gun alignment was adjusted without documentation. Product quality was not impacted. Documentation controls were reinforced.
A supplier CoA listed test methods not aligned with approved specifications. Additional testing was performed prior to release.
An internal review identified that periodic review of alarm limits had not been performed per SOP schedule.
A deviation was opened due to repeated minor pressure fluctuations in a cleanroom during peak personnel movement. Procedural controls were updated.
An operator selected an incorrect cleaning cycle on automated equipment. The issue was identified before equipment release.
A batch failed assay uniformity during final testing. Investigation identified inadequate mixing time. The batch was rejected.
A deviation was recorded for incomplete documentation of maintenance activity start time. Maintenance records confirmed completion.
During stability testing, a refrigerator alarm was acknowledged late. Temperature remained within acceptable limits.
A training deviation occurred when SOP retraining was not triggered following a minor revision.
An equipment interlock failed to engage during setup testing. Engineering replaced a faulty sensor before use.
A deviation was opened when blend samples were mislabeled during transport to the lab. Samples were re-collected.
Supplier-provided extractables data was incomplete for a new packaging component. Additional data was requested before approval.
Environmental monitoring incubator calibration was found overdue during audit. No impacted results were identified.
An operator failed to follow proper gown removal sequence when exiting a controlled area. The incident was observed and corrected.
A deviation was initiated when a batch yield calculation spreadsheet used an incorrect rounding rule. No release impact occurred.
During compression, feeder speed fluctuated due to worn drive belts. The batch was placed on hold and later rejected.
A deviation was opened due to delayed QA review of deviation investigation beyond target timelines.
A supplier shipment was received without temperature monitoring data. Material was rejected.
An operator misinterpreted a cleaning verification acceptance limit. Results were within specification.

During routine review of in-process control data, a transient spike in granulation torque was observed outside the historical operating range, though within validated limits. Investigation determined the spike coincided with manual addition of binder solution at a slightly increased flow rate. No impact to granule quality attributes was identified based on subsequent testing. The deviation was documented to reinforce adherence to controlled addition rates and monitoring expectations.

A temperature excursion occurred in the stability chamber during weekend hours when the backup power supply failed to engage immediately following a brief power outage. Chamber temperature remained above the setpoint for approximately 45 minutes. Stability data and excursion impact assessment confirmed no effect on stored samples. Maintenance performed corrective actions on the backup system.

During batch record review, it was identified that one page of the executed record was scanned upside down, resulting in reduced legibility in the electronic archive. The original hardcopy record was reviewed and confirmed complete and accurate. The deviation addressed record archiving and scanning practices.

An OOT trend was identified for dissolution results during annual product review. Although all results remained within specification, investigation linked the trend to gradual wear of compression tooling. Preventive replacement of tooling was implemented to restore process capability.

A deviation was initiated when incoming excipient containers arrived with damaged outer cartons, potentially compromising cleanliness. The inner liners were intact, and additional inspection confirmed material suitability. The incident was documented to reinforce supplier shipping controls.

During cleaning of a fluid bed dryer, the operator omitted documentation of one intermediate inspection step. Review of equipment status and cleaning results confirmed acceptable cleanliness. The deviation addressed contemporaneous documentation requirements.

An internal audit identified that periodic review of environmental monitoring alert and action limits had not been completed within the required timeframe. No adverse environmental trends were identified. The deviation addressed quality system oversight.

A tablet press experienced intermittent weight control alarms during startup. Investigation identified a misaligned feeder component. Adjustments were made prior to batch start, and no product was impacted.

During dispensing, an operator staged two similar-looking raw material containers closer than allowed by SOP. Independent verification prevented mix-up. The deviation reinforced material segregation requirements.

Environmental monitoring results showed elevated non-viable particle counts during a maintenance activity conducted adjacent to a Grade C area. Investigation confirmed the activity was not adequately coordinated. Procedural controls were updated.
A deviation was opened when an analyst used an incorrect injection volume during HPLC analysis. The error was identified during data review, and samples were reanalyzed correctly.

A balance used for dispensing failed post-use verification, indicating potential drift during operation. Secondary checks confirmed dispensed weights were accurate. The balance was removed from service for calibration.

Training records indicated that refresher training on a revised cleaning SOP was completed after initial equipment use. No cleaning deficiencies were observed. The deviation addressed training assignment timing.
A deviation was initiated due to delayed transfer of samples to long-term stability storage following pull. Samples remained under controlled conditions. No data integrity issues were identified.

During warehouse inspection, a pallet of finished goods was found positioned partially outside the designated temperature mapping zone. Data review confirmed acceptable conditions. The deviation addressed storage discipline.
An SOP governing deviation management referenced an obsolete internal form. The deviation was documented to update documentation and ensure consistency.
A blister packaging machine sealing jaw temperature briefly dropped below the validated minimum due to a sensor fault. Product inspection confirmed seal integrity. The sensor was replaced.
An analyst deviated from the validated vortexing time during sample preparation. The deviation was identified during peer review, and testing was repeated.
A supplier provided an updated CoA format without prior notification. All required data were present. The deviation addressed supplier communication expectations.
Environmental monitoring samples were collected outside the defined time window due to staffing constraints. Results were acceptable. Scheduling controls were reviewed.
During filling operations, an in-process fill weight check was performed late due to line stoppage. Subsequent checks were compliant. Risk assessment supported batch release.
A deviation was recorded when reconciliation documentation for returned bulk containers was completed using an outdated template. Physical reconciliation was accurate.
An unplanned shutdown of the clean steam generator occurred during routine monitoring. No use points were active at the time.
A training deviation was opened when aseptic gowning observation was not documented for one operator during the qualification period.
A batch experienced extended solution hold time due to downstream equipment maintenance. Stability data supported acceptability of the extended hold.
Minor flaking paint was observed on a non-product contact ceiling beam in a manufacturing corridor. Facilities initiated repair.
An operator entered an incorrect lot number suffix in an electronic logbook. The error was corrected with appropriate justification and audit trail.
A deviation was opened when an HPLC detector lamp reached end-of-life earlier than anticipated. No data impact was identified.
Incoming printed components arrived with inconsistent pallet IDs. Components were verified and segregated prior to release.
Environmental monitoring results showed an isolated action-level recovery attributed to inadequate cleaning of a rarely used cart. Corrective cleaning was performed.
A deviation was initiated when an SOP training acknowledgment was completed without required assessment. Assessment was subsequently completed.
During coating operations, exhaust airflow was temporarily reduced due to damper malfunction. Coating parameters remained within limits.
A supplier stability summary for a critical excipient was missing long-term data. Additional documentation was obtained prior to approval.
Periodic review of laboratory alarm limits was completed late due to resource constraints. No alarm events were missed.
A deviation was opened due to increased personnel traffic near a controlled area during a facility tour. Environmental data remained acceptable.
An operator selected an incorrect pre-programmed cycle for equipment cleaning. The issue was identified before equipment release.
A batch failed blend uniformity acceptance criteria during final testing. Investigation identified inadequate blending time. The batch was rejected.
A deviation was recorded for missing documentation of maintenance tool calibration. Calibration records were later retrieved.
A stability chamber alarm was acknowledged late, but temperature remained within allowable range throughout.
A training deviation occurred when SOP retraining effectiveness was not assessed following revision.
An equipment safety interlock failed verification during routine testing. The equipment was locked out pending repair.
A deviation was opened when blend samples were temporarily stored outside the designated container type. Samples were re-collected.
Supplier-provided microbial limit testing data did not reference the current pharmacopeial chapter. Clarification was obtained.
Environmental monitoring incubator humidity control was found non-functional. Incubation conditions remained acceptable.
An operator briefly contacted a non-classified surface during gowning qualification. The run was invalidated.
A deviation was initiated when a batch yield calculation used preliminary weights instead of final reconciled values. No release impact occurred.
During compression, force control drifted due to hydraulic pressure instability. The batch was placed on hold and later rejected.
A deviation was opened due to delayed closure of a CAPA effectiveness check. No recurrence of the issue was observed.
A supplier shipment arrived without required humidity indicator cards. Material was placed on hold pending assessment.
An operator misunderstood cleaning acceptance criteria during visual inspection. QA review confirmed acceptable condition.

During routine in-process checks, tablet thickness measurements showed increased variability compared to historical trends, though still within specification. Investigation determined that minor wear on compression rollers contributed to the variability. No impact to finished product quality was identified. Preventive maintenance scheduling for roller inspection was revised to prevent recurrence.

A temperature excursion occurred in the finished goods staging area when a dock door remained open longer than expected during loading activities. Data review confirmed that product temperatures remained within acceptable limits. The deviation was documented to reinforce warehouse loading controls.

During batch record review, it was identified that one non-critical field was completed using an incorrect date format. The error was corrected with appropriate justification. The deviation addressed documentation accuracy expectations.

An OOS result was generated for friability during in-process testing. Investigation identified insufficient lubricant distribution due to premature discharge from the blender. The batch was rejected due to potential impact on tablet robustness.

A deviation was initiated when incoming printed packaging components arrived without updated revision identifiers. Components were quarantined until verification against approved artwork was completed.

During routine cleaning verification, a small amount of residue was observed in a hard-to-access equipment joint. The cleaning SOP did not explicitly address this location. The equipment was re-cleaned and the SOP updated.
An internal audit identified that periodic review of computerized system user access had not been completed within the required timeframe. No unauthorized access was detected.
A capsule filling machine experienced intermittent stoppages due to sensor misalignment. The issue was corrected prior to batch start. No product was impacted.

During dispensing, two raw materials with similar names were staged adjacent to each other, contrary to SOP requirements. Independent verification prevented a mix-up. The deviation reinforced segregation controls.

Environmental monitoring data showed elevated non-viable particle counts during a maintenance activity conducted nearby. Investigation confirmed that barriers were not fully deployed. Procedural controls were strengthened.
A deviation was opened when an analyst used an outdated worksheet template during analytical testing. Calculations were verified and found correct. Documentation controls were reinforced.
A balance failed daily verification due to mechanical wear. Review confirmed no dispensing activities occurred since the last acceptable check.
Training records indicated that refresher training on a revised deviation SOP was completed after initial use. No errors were identified. The deviation addressed training timing.
A deviation was initiated due to delayed initiation of a stability pull beyond the scheduled window. Samples remained under controlled conditions. No impact was identified.
During warehouse inspection, a pallet of API drums was found positioned too close to a wall, restricting airflow. Data review confirmed no temperature impact.
An SOP governing environmental monitoring referenced an obsolete sampling location. The deviation was documented to update procedural accuracy.
A blister packaging machine sealing pressure briefly exceeded the validated range due to controller lag. Inspection confirmed acceptable seals.
An analyst deviated from the validated extraction time during sample preparation. The issue was identified during peer review and testing was repeated.
A supplier notified of a minor process change after shipment of excipient material. Risk assessment confirmed no impact to quality.
Environmental monitoring plates were incubated at the lower end of the acceptable temperature range due to incubator drift. No adverse trends were observed.
During filling operations, an in-process volume check was performed late due to line stoppage. Subsequent checks met acceptance criteria.
A deviation was recorded when reconciliation documentation for returned printed components was signed using initials rather than full signature.
An unplanned shutdown of the clean-in-place system occurred during routine maintenance. No equipment was in use at the time.
A training deviation was opened when aseptic technique observation was not documented for one operator within the qualification period.
A batch experienced extended solution hold time due to delayed availability of downstream equipment. Stability data supported acceptability.
Minor surface rust was observed on a non-product contact ladder within the manufacturing area. Facilities initiated corrective maintenance.
An operator entered an incorrect equipment ID in the electronic logbook. The error was corrected with audit trail documentation.
A deviation was opened when an HPLC pump seal failed during routine system suitability testing. No samples were affected.
Incoming cartons of printed labels arrived with mixed orientation, increasing handling risk. Components were inspected prior to use.
Environmental monitoring results showed an isolated action-level recovery attributed to inadequate cleaning of a mobile cart. Corrective actions were implemented.
A deviation was initiated when an SOP training acknowledgment was completed without an accompanying effectiveness assessment.
During coating operations, exhaust airflow was temporarily reduced due to damper sticking. Coating parameters remained within limits.
A supplier-provided CoA listed an incorrect specification reference. Clarification was obtained prior to material release.
Periodic review of alarm response logs was completed late due to staffing constraints. No missed alarms were identified.
A deviation was opened due to increased foot traffic near a controlled area during a site visit. Environmental data remained acceptable.
An operator selected an incorrect automated cleaning cycle. The error was identified before equipment release.
A batch failed assay acceptance criteria during release testing. Investigation identified inadequate mixing time. The batch was rejected.
A deviation was recorded for missing documentation of maintenance tool calibration. Records were later retrieved.
A stability chamber alarm was acknowledged late; temperature remained within acceptable range throughout.
A training deviation occurred when SOP retraining effectiveness was not assessed following revision.
An equipment safety interlock failed during routine verification testing. Equipment was locked out pending repair.
A deviation was opened when blend samples were temporarily stored outside the designated container type. Samples were re-collected.
Supplier-provided microbial testing data referenced an outdated pharmacopeial chapter. Updated documentation was obtained.
Environmental monitoring incubator humidity control malfunctioned. Incubation conditions remained within acceptable limits.
An operator contacted a non-classified surface during gowning qualification. The run was invalidated and retraining completed.
A deviation was initiated when a batch yield calculation used preliminary values instead of reconciled weights. No release impact occurred.
During compression, hydraulic pressure instability caused force drift. The batch was placed on hold and subsequently rejected.
A deviation was opened due to delayed closure of a CAPA effectiveness check. No recurrence of the issue was observed.
A supplier shipment arrived without required temperature monitoring documentation. Material was placed on hold pending assessment.
An operator misunderstood visual cleanliness acceptance criteria during inspection. QA review confirmed acceptable condition.
